objects.textBefore:
/-
# Proving left cancellation.


Our first goal is to prove that we have left cancellation in a group. 

More precisely, given elements `a`, `b`, and `c` in our group $G$, if `a*b=a*c` then `b=c`. 

But before we can do that, we need to know what axioms we are starting with. Lean defines a group as having associativity, an identity, and an inverse.#check

In particular, you can see the these properties written in Lean below. 

-/


import algebra.group 
variables {G : Type*} [group G] -- hide

#check (mul_assoc : ∀ a b c : G, a * b * c = a * (b * c))
#check (one_mul : ∀ a : G, 1 * a = a)
#check (mul_left_inv : ∀ a : G, a⁻¹ * a = 1)

namespace my_group -- hide

/- 
The `#check` means we are asking Lean to check if these are true for our group `G`. And thankfully they are! 

We will prove our first lemma, left cancellation, using these properties along with a single tactic: `rw`. 

This tactic stands for rewrite. For example, if we had a hypothesis `h` that states `X=Y`, then `rw h,` would rewrite every `X` in our goal to a `Y`.

For example, I recommend the first line `rw ← one_mul b,` which rewrites the goal `b=c` by replacing the `b` with `1*b`.

The left arrow symbol, `←`, which you can get by writing `\l`, reads the hypothesis in reverse. For example, `one_mul` says that `1*b=b` but we wanted to replace `b` with `1*b`, so we needed a `←`.
-/

/- Lemma
For $a$, $b$, and $c$, in a group $G$, if `a*b=a*c` then `b=c`. 
-/
theorem mul_left_cancel(a b c : G)(h1: a*b=a*c): b=c :=
begin
objects.proof:
rw ← one_mul b,
    rw ← mul_left_inv a,
    rw mul_assoc, 
    rw h1, 
    rw ← mul_assoc,
    rw mul_left_inv,
    rw one_mul,
objects.textAfter:
end
end my_group --hide
/- Tactic : rw
The code `rw` rewrites our goal using a hypothesis `h`. For example, if our goal is `b=c` and we have the hypothesis `h: b=a`, then `rw h,` will get you `a=c`.

Remember you can use `←` to swith the order of the hypothesis. 
-/

/-
## Solution
Here you can reveal the solution to this level, one line at a time. If stuck, I encourage you to only reveal upto the point you were stuck, and then try from there!

For this first level, I recommend liberal use of this solution! 
<details>
  <summary>Solution Line 1</summary>

</details>
<details>

        `rw ← mul_left_inv a,`
</details>
<details>
  <summary>Solution Line 3</summary>
        `rw mul_assoc, `
</details>
<details>
  <summary>Solution Line 4</summary>
        `rw h1,`
</details>
<details>

        `rw ← mul_assoc,`
</details>
<details>
  <summary>Solution Line 6</summary>
        `rw mul_left_inv,`
</details>
<details>
  <summary>Solution Line 7</summary>
        `rw one_mul,`
</details>
-/
objects.name: mul_left_cancel

objects.textBefore:
/-
# Using Apply to Prove Right Identity Multiplication.


In Lean, proving left cancellation is a very powerful result.

This is because it allows us to left multiply an equation by any element of the group.

We do this using the code `apply`. For example, if we have `a=b` then `apply mul_left_cancel c` will left multiply by `c`.

To demonstrate this, we will try to prove that `a*1=a` for all `a` in `G`. 

Remember, we don't know this yet, since our axiom only tells us that `1*a=a` for all `a` in `G`, but nothing about right hand side multiplication.

For the first line of code, I suggest `apply mul_left_cancel a⁻¹`, which multiplies both sides of `b=c` by `a⁻¹`. You can write `a⁻¹` by writing `a\inv`.

Again, if you get stuck, the solution is below. Remember, the only tools we have right now are `rw`, `apply`, our axioms, and `mul_left_cancel`.

-/

import algebra.group  -- hide
import levels.group_props.left_cancel --hide
variables {G : Type*} [group G] --hide 

namespace my_group  --hide

/- Lemma
For $a$ in a group $G$, `a*1=a`. 
-/
lemma mul_one (a : G) : a * 1 = a :=
begin
objects.proof:
apply mul_left_cancel a⁻¹,
    rw ← mul_assoc,
    rw mul_left_inv,
    rw one_mul,
objects.textAfter:
end
end my_group --hide

/- Tactic : apply
The code `apply` lets us apply a theorem. For example, we have left cancellation: `a*b=a*c` implies `b=c`. So if we have `d=e` we can apply left cancellation in reverse and write `f*d=f*e` for any `f`.

We do this by `apply mul_left_cancel f,`.
-/

/-
## Solution
<details>
  <summary>Solution Line 1</summary>
        `apply mul_left_cancel a⁻¹,`
</details>
<details>
  <summary>Solution Line 2</summary>
        `rw ← mul_assoc,`
</details>
<details>
  <summary>Solution Line 3</summary>
        `rw mul_left_inv,`
</details>
<details>
  <summary>Solution Line 4</summary>
        `rw one_mul,`
</details>
-/
objects.name: mul_one

    rw one_mul,

/-
# Proving Right Cancellation

Now that we've proven that we can have inverses and identities on the right, we can tackle right cancellation.

Once we prove this, we can start to solve equations in groups, since we can left and right multiply!

This is the final boss of the world, so good luck!

import algebra.group  -- hide
import levels.group_props.left_cancel --hide
variables {G : Type*} [group G] --hide 

namespace my_group  --hide

lemma mul_right_cancel(a b c : G)(h1: b*a=c*a): b=c :=
begin
objects.proof:
rw ← mul_one b,
   rw ← mul_right_inv a, 
   rw ← mul_assoc,
   rw h1,
   rw mul_assoc, 
   rw mul_right_inv,
   rw mul_one,
objects.textAfter:
end
end my_group --hide

/-
# Proving If and Only If Statements

Now that we've proven some basic group properties, we look to prove some different types of theorems. 

As the title alludes to, we look to prove if and only if statements. For example, in a group we know that the identity is unique.

So we want to prove that *a*b=b* if and only if *a=1*. We write this as we write most lemmas, but now use the `↔` symbol which you can get by typing `\iff`.

Then, to prove the seperate cases we start with the code `split,`. This allows us to prove one case at a time. 

After this, we can use `intro h`, which gives us a specific hypothesis `h` to represent our condition. 

For example, our first case will be `a*b = b → a =1`. So `intro h,` will give us the hypothesis `h: a*b=b`.

-/

import algebra.group  -- hide
import levels.group_props.level4 --hide
variables {G : Type*} [group G] --hide 

namespace my_group  --hide

/- Lemma
For a group `G`, `a*b=b` if and only if `a=1`. 
-/
lemma unique_identity {a b : G} : a * b = b ↔ a = 1 :=
begin
objects.proof:
split,
    intro h,
    apply mul_right_cancel b,
    rw one_mul,
    rw h,
    intro h,
    rw h,
    rw one_mul,
objects.textAfter:
end
end my_group --hide

/- Tactic : split
The code `split,` splits an if and only if statement into two separate goals you have to prove. 

-/
/- Tactic : intro
The code `intro` gives you a specific hypothesis of a general condition.

For example, if we have that ` b*a=a*b → a=c` then `intro h,` will give us `h: b*a=a*b`.
-/


/-

</details>

/-
# Solving Problems

Having proven same basic group properties, we can solve some problems! I went and looked at my old Abstract Algebra textbook - A First Course in Abstract Algebra by John B. Fraleigh - and found two problems suitable for us to solve.#check

Besides the tactics we've discussed in the previous world, there is one thing that can be helpful.

The code `simp [theorem]` tries to simplify the goal using the theorem. This is especially helpful for something like `mul_assoc`, which can be tricky when operating on many elements. 

So `simp [mul_assoc]` is recommended. 

-/

import algebra.group  -- hide
import levels.group_props.level4 --hide
variables {G : Type*} [group G] --hide 

namespace my_group  --hide

/- Lemma
For a group `G`, if `(a*b)*(a*b)=a*a*b*b` then `b*a=a*b`. 
-/
lemma problem1 (a b :G)(h: (a*b)*(a*b)=a*a*b*b): b*a=a*b :=
begin
objects.proof:
apply mul_right_cancel b,
    apply mul_left_cancel a,
    rw ←  mul_assoc,
    rw ← mul_assoc,
    rw ← mul_assoc, 
    rw ← mul_assoc,
    rw ← h,
    simp [mul_assoc],
objects.textAfter:
end
end my_group --hide

The code `simp,` tries to known theorems to simplify the goal.
